node.statement: (Well-definedness of duality pairings) Given :phi^3: in C^{-3/2-delta}(T^3) and :phi^2: in C^{-1-delta}(T^3) for any delta > 0, and psi in C^inf(T^3), the following duality pairings are well-defined: (a) <psi, :phi^3:> := integral_{T^3} psi(x) :phi^3:(x) dx is the pairing of C^{3/2+delta'}(T^3) with C^{-3/2-delta}(T^3). Since psi in C^inf subset C^{3/2+delta'} for any delta' > 0, and the duality pairing between C^alpha and C^{-beta} is well-defined as a continuous bilinear map whenever alpha + beta > 0 (which holds since (3/2+delta') + (3/2+delta) > 0 for any delta, delta' > 0), this gives a well-defined real number. (b) <psi^2, :phi^2:> := integral_{T^3} psi(x)^2 :phi^2:(x) dx is the pairing of C^{1+delta'}(T^3) with C^{-1-delta}(T^3). Since psi^2 in C^inf subset C^{1+delta'} for any delta' > 0, and (1+delta') + (1+delta) > 0, this is also well-defined. The continuity of these bilinear pairings ensures that phi |-> <psi, :phi^3:> and phi |-> <psi^2, :phi^2:> are measurable maps from (D'(T^3), B(D'(T^3))) to (R, B(R)), hence well-defined random variables under any Borel probability measure on D'(T^3), in particular under mu.
